contentrichtext.text: {{For|the basketball player|Fred Foster (basketball)}} {{BLP sources|date=July 2010}} '''Fred Foster''' (born '''Fred Luther Foster''', July 26, 1931, [[Rutherford County, North Carolina|Rutherford County]], [[North Carolina]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[songwriter]], [[record producer]], and founder of [[Monument Records]].<ref name="Unterberger">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p77128/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography: Fred Foster|last=Unterberger|first=Richie|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=22 July 2010}}</ref> ==Biography== Born in North Carolina, Foster struggled to support his mother after the death of his father. At the age of seventeen, Foster left the farm and moved to [[Washington, D.C.]], where he would eventually work for [[Mercury Records]] and [[ABC-Paramount Records]] (1955). In March 1958, Foster used his life savings and formed the Monument Records with minority partner, Buddy Deane (a [[disc jockey]] at [[WITH (FM)|WITH]]). In 1959, Deane sold his stock back to Foster, and Foster re-located the label to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in 1960. Foster remained active with the label until 1983. Foster is credited with the development of [[Roy Orbison]]'s career, producing many of Orbison's major hits, including: "[[Oh, Pretty Woman]]", "[[Only the Lonely]]", "[[Running Scared (song)|Running Scared]]", "[[In Dreams (song)|In Dreams]]", and "[[Crying (Roy Orbison song)|Crying]]", "[[It's Over (Roy Orbison song)|It's Over]]", "[[Mean Woman Blues]]", "[[Candy Man (Roy Orbison song)|Candy Man]]", and "[[Blue Bayou]]". Foster also played a significant role in [[Dolly Parton]]'s early career, signing her to Monument in 1964, shortly after her arrival in Nashville, and overseeing her recordings, culminating with her first top 40 country hit "[[Hello, I'm Dolly|Dumb Blonde]]" in 1967. Foster also produced [[Billy Grammer]], [[Ray Stevens]], [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[Tony Joe White]], [[Larry Gatlin]], [[Charlie McCoy]], [[Al Hirt]], [[Boots Randolph]], [[Jerry Byrd]], [[Billy Joe Shaver]], [[Grandpa Jones]], [[The Velvets]] and [[Robert Mitchum]]. In 1963, Foster expanded his label, forming the [[soul music|soul]] and [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] imprint called [[Sound Stage 7]]. Its roster of artists included [[Joe Simon (musician)|Joe Simon]], [[The Dixie Belles]], [[Arthur Alexander]], and [[Ivory Joe Hunter]]. Foster co-wrote (with [[Kris Kristofferson]]) "[[Me and Bobby McGee]]", which was a hit for Kristofferson, plus [[Bobbie Gentry]] and [[Janis Joplin]]. More recently, Foster produced [[Willie Nelson]]'s 2006 [[Grammy Award]] nominated ''[[You Don't Know Me: The Songs of Cindy Walker]]'', and Nelson's collaboration with [[Merle Haggard]] and [[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]], ''[[Last of the Breed (album)|Last of the Breed]]'' (2007). The latter was the winner of 2008 Grammy for Best Country Collaboration for the track, "Lost Highway". Foster was inducted into the [[Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum]] on October 12, 2009. <ref>http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1623747/rascal-flatts-perform-with-toto-during-musicians-hall-of-fame-induction-ceremony.jhtml</ref> He will be inducted into the [[North Carolina Music Hall of Fame]] on October 11, 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=N.C. Music Hall of Fame offers tickets|url=http://www.salisburypost.com/News/082912WEB--NC-Music-HAll--of-F|accessdate=September 10, 2012|newspaper=The Salisbury Post|date=August 29, 2012}}</ref> == References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control|VIAF=31242527}} {{Persondata | NAME = Foster, Fred | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American record producer | DATE OF BIRTH = July 26, 1931 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Rutherford County, North Carolina | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Foster, Fred}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Rutherford County, North Carolina]] [[Category:American record producers]] [[Category:Songwriters from North Carolina]] [[Category:North Carolina Music Hall of Fame inductees]]
